South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

Special express Itinerary arriving Piraeus Friday evenings and Constantinople Saturday afternoons omitting Smyrna and Mitylene outwards.
PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, and MERSINA calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.
SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for TOR (for Sinai. YAMBO and JEDDAH, and continuing in the alternate weeks to PORT SUDAN, SUAKIM, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAH and ADEN.
For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

FRIDAY, MAY 24, 1907.

div.head: EMPIRE DAY.
div.p: God of our fathers, known of old, Lord of our far-flung battle-line. Beneath whose awful Hand we hold Dominion over palm and pine— Lord God of Hosts, be with us yet. Lest we forget—lest we forget.

If, drunk with night of power, we loose Wild tongues that have not Thee in awe, Such boasting an the Gentiles use Or leaser breeds without the Law- Lord God of Hosts, be with us yet. Lest we forget —lest we forget.

We have once more reached that day now recognised throughout the breadth of the vast British Empire, the celebration of which, in the words of Lord Meath, the originator of the "Empire Day" movement, "shall be the outward sign of an inner awakening of the peoples who constitute the British Empire to the serious duties which lie at their doors." The first celebration of Empire Day was made on May 24, 1904, and though on that occasion the chain of celebration around the earth's surface was not continuous, it has in the last two years been made complete, as far as the self-governing and Crown colonies of the Mother Land are concerned. It was on May 24, 1819. that was born Victoria the Well-Beloved, during whose reign the British Empire reached its present power, greatness, and unity, and it is, therefore, only natural that our late Queen's birthday should be celebrated as "Empire Day." We feel sure that much good has been done by the formation of an Empire day by Lord Meath and his colleagues. It is not so much the outward demonstrations which are useful to the Empire as, to use the promoter's words, "the subordination of selfish or class interests to those of the State and the Community, and the inculcation on the minds of all British subjects of the honourable obligation which rests upon them of preparing themselves, each in his or her own sphere, for the due fulfilment of the duties and responsibilities attached to the high privilege of being the subjects of the mightiest Empire which the world has ever known."

It is the object of the Empire Day movement to promote amongst the rising generation a deeper sense of patriotic and of civic duty ; and how can these objects be most effectively accomplished ? In the first place support should be given to any efforts which may be made by my parents and teachers to instil into the minds of the young the importance of unselfishness, respect, and obedience to lawful authority; the watchwords of the movement are "responsibility, duty, sympathy, and self-sacrifice," and without these qualities no individual and no nation can be truly great. Speaking at Exeter Hall on May 24, 1905, Lord Meath said:— "What are the principal causes of internal decay and disruption as exemplified by the fate of other Empires ? (1) Spiritual and moral atrophy in the body politic, leading to public and private corruption, to immorality and luck of public spirit. (2) The growth of enervating luxury and the spirit of selfishness, making men and women soft, weakening their minds and bodies, making them careless of the rights and wants of others, and inclined to subordinate the public to selfish or class interests. (3) Want of interest in, and adequate knowledge of, the affairs of the Commonwealth, thus placing the masses at the mercy of clever and unscrupulous men, seeking their own private interests to the detriment of the general welfare. These are a few of the causes which have led to the decay and fall of nations. Are we quite sure that some of the above causes of decay have not already been sown in our own midst ? If so, let us who believe in the "Empire Day" movement endeavour to eradicate them in time. Are there not too many of every class who never look at a question except through their own selfish spectacles, and yet are most indignant when others do the same ?"

And what is the duty of those who are of the British Empire, and yet do not five within its territories? It is for none of us in any wise lessened, and for us, resident in a country which Great Britain has undertaken to conduct to the level of Western civilization, the responsibility of Empire is vastly increased. It us for us, daily examples of Britain's worth, to impress upon those, the care and education of whom our nation has adopted, that
Our word is peace, our rights are equal laws, Our arms of love we spread from sea to sea, Our life is progress toward the broader cause Our hope, through justice, to give liberty.

div.head: Strike at Matarieh.
div.p: A large number of fisherman have gone on strike at Matarieh as a protest against the imposition of new regulations.

div.head: The Rudolph Home.
div.p: The Alexandria Bonded Warehouse and the British Benevolent Society have each given £5 to the Rudolph Home in memory of the late Sydney H. Carver.

div.head: Khedivial Distinction.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has graciously conferred the title of Salissa on Emin el Soliman, ex-engineer of the Tanzim Administration on the occasion of his resignation.

div.head: Pigs at Port Said.
div.p: The Quarantine Board has decided to make an annotation on the bills of health delivered at the Egyptian ports to the effect that pneumoenteritis exists among the pigs at Port Said.

div.head: The S.S. Adelphotes.
div.p: The Greek S.S. Adelphotes, which grounded on a roof to the west of El Agami a few weeks ago, went into the dry dock at (Gabbari to day in order to be repaired before proceeding to Marseilles.

div.head: The Jesuits College.
div.p: On Sunday next there will be a dramatic and musical entertainment at the Jesuits' College, Alexandria, which will be under the patronage of the French Consul. The entertainment will begin at 4 p.m.

div.head: Alexandria Archaeological Society.
div.p: The excursion which was to have been made to Saint Menas City yesterday has been postponed to the autumn in consequence of the heat. The Alexandria Archaeological Society is determined to make this interesting trip as soon as the cool weather arrives.

div.head: Horrible Suicide.
div.p: Yesterday a native named Mohamed Aly, of Cairo, who for some months past has been suffering from an ineurable disease, decided to put an end to his life. He accordingly opened his abdomen with such determination that his intestines came out. He was taken to hospital in a precarious state.

div.head: Forthcoming Concert.
div.p: On Monday, the 3rd proxo., an interesting concert is to be held at Alexandria on the occasion of the inauguration of the new Sala Lifonti in Rosetta Gate-street. The celebrated violinist, Signor Serato, will take part in the concert. Full details of this concert will be published in our columns in a few days' time.

div.head: Plague.
div.p: For the past 24 hours the following cases of plague are reported: One death out of hospital at Alexandria ; 1 death in hospital at Beni- Mazar ; 1 death at Samaillout ; 3 deaths and 1 case declared cured at Mellawi ; 1 case and 1 death in hospital at Deirout also 1 death out of hospital ; 1 new ease and 1 death at Esneh. 66 patients are still under treatment.

div.head: Interesting Memoirs.
div.p: Many people will he interested to hear that Sir Henry Drummond Wolff has consented to write the recollections of his life. Needless to say these will be awaited with great interest, for few men have played a more prominent part in both home and foreign politics during the past half century. Sir Henry was one of the leading spirits of the famous Fourth Party, which was so piquant a factor in the British Parliament years ago, and his intimate connection with Egyptian and Turkish affairs will lend great importance to his references to the history of the British Occupation, in Egypt. The reminiscences will fill two volumes, and will be published by Messrs. Macmillan.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Ministers, with the exception of Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Works, will arrive at Alexandria for the summer season to day.
Sir Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser, is arriving at Alexandria to day.
The Countess von Bernsdorff, wife of the German Minister, left Cairo yesterday for Said to
embark for Europe with her daughter. Count von Bernsdorff is going on four months' leave at the end of June.
Baron von Slatin Pasha, K.C.M.G, C.B., will leave Alexandria to-morrow for Austria by the Austrian Lloyd steamer.
Saad Zagloul Pasha is expected at Alexandria to-morrow and has reserved an appartment at the Savoy Palace Hotel.
M. Chevaudrier de Valdrome, 1st Secretary of the French Agency, is leaving for Europe today on two and a half months' leave.

Mrs. Logan and Mrs. Richmond take this opportunity of informing their guests for 1st June that owing to a change in the time table train for Aboukir will leave Sidi Gaber at 2 p.m., and not 2.10 p.m. as previously announced.
Capt. Francesco Loschiavo, moawin of the secret police of Cairo, has been granted three and a half months' leave of absence dating from the 1st proxo.

div.head:
THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
WILD FLUCTUATIONS IN LONDON.
EXCITEMENT ON LONDON STOCK EXCHANGE.
MARKET CLOSES FIRMER.
div.p: LONDON, Friday.

Egyptian Share market on the London Stock Exchange has been fluctuating in a wild manner during the last few days. The shares in Egyptian companies offered here have been taken at low prices, but the market closes with a firmer tone all round.

There will be a meeting this evening at the offices of the National Bank of Egypt at Alexandria when the directors of the local banks and the heads of the private banking establishments, who have expressed their readiness to join the syndicate, will meet to discuss the final details.

The shrinkage in values in Egyptian stocks and slares from the 28th April last to the day on which the Cairo and Alexandria Stock and Sharebrokers Associations fixed the rates of compensation amounted to £12,600,000. Since that date the shrinkage has increased on an enormous scale and the depreciation amounts to a total of many more millions sterling.

Considerable anxiety is felt as to the effect which the financial crisis will have on land. Agricultural laud was never on a sounder basis than it is to-day as the purchasing capacities of the fellah have never been greater. The danger lies in the suburban building laud in Cairo and Alexandria and already there has been considerable depreciation owing to enforced sales. For example a short time ago the owner of a plot of land at Chatby refused an offer of P.T. 210 per pic for it. He was forced to sell the identical plot the other day at the rate of P.T. 55 per pic. In the Halte Cleopatra district a landowner refused P.T. 160 per pic lately for some lamd which he was obliged to dispose of at P.T. 65 a few days ago. The same tale is told at Cairo and there are a huge number of protests, lodged in the Cairn Mixed Courts in regard to non payments on land transactions.

It has been said that orders from Europe are waiting in some of the local banks to buy shares to a certain extent. Even if this report be true there is , but slight chance of any help being forthcoming from Europe. At the present time all the European stock and share markets are dull and the persistent stagnation of business has been puzzling European financiers for some time past. For example at home speculation has quite died out for the time being and the public are doing very little in the way of investment. The investment market has ubsolutely failed to respond to Mr. Asquith'S Budget, though the amount of Consols to be purchased during the current year will be £15,800,000. Consols actually fell after the Budget ; and other gilt-edged securities are perfectly lifeless. As the Board of Trade returns leave no doubt as to the increasing volume of exports and imports (the buoyancy of British commerce being greater than ever before), and as money is more plentiful and cheaper, the Bank Rate being reduced from 6 to 4 since the New Year, the question as to what is the hidden malady, which seems to paralyse investment is being continually asked. When such a state of things is the order of the day in England, there is no chance of the ridiculously low price of many excellent- Egyptian securities being likely to induce the investing public to come foreword at the present moment.

At a meeting of the representatives of the newspapers of Cairo, held on Wednesday afternoon at the Cercle Artistique with a view to decide upon some measures to stay the present financial crisis in Egypt, the following resolutions were taken :-
1. That the present financial depression was largely due to the distrust prevailing in European financial centres where financiers were afraid to speculate upon Egyptian values.
2. That this distrust had been largely produced by the exaggerated reports of social agitation, intranquillity and even danger to Europeans in the Nile Valley.

3. That, as regarded Egypt, the crisis had been produced (a) by European distrust ; (b) by the deceptive census returns hastening the fall in the price of land in the Cairo suburbs ; (c) by the unwillingness of the banks to come to the aid of the situation and of commercial enterprises.
"Qui s'excuse, s'accuse," and the second resolution appears to have somewhat agitated the "Egyptian Standard." The English organ of Mustapha Pasha Kamel exclaims :-
We uphold the opinions we have always stated in "The Egyptian Standard," "l'Etendard Egyptien" and "Al Lewa."
But, and as regards the supposed poltical agitation in Egypt, we wish is to be clearly understood that none of these organs above named ever had a hand in the spreading of such a rumour.

From the very first, and in every issue, we have energetically denied that such an agitation existed, and have proved that the accusations brought against us and against the Egyptian nation were entirely unfounded (sic).

Thus, in asserting it once again to-day and in unison with the whole Egyptian press, we do but repeat what we have asserted since the very first number of "The Egyptian Standard," namely that : there is no agitation of any kind in Egypt and that it is our earnest wish to see the most cordial relations existing between Egyptians and the foreign residents in Egypt (sic).
Upon this entente cordiale depends to a very great extent the future of the Egyptian nation, and let it never be said that we have not been the first to stretch forth a fraternal hand.

div.head:
THE CENSUS
DEFECTIVE ORGANISATION.
div.p: Owing to the many proofs that have been forthcoming of the haphazard way in which the recent census was taken, the Government is considering the advisability of going over the operation a second time Many well-known residents of Alexandria and Cairo, who inhabit their own houses, were never visited by the census officials at all. The other day eight English residents at Cairo were discussiug the extraordinarily small increase in the population of the capital as revealed by the last census, when they discovered that only one of their names had been put on the census lists. In another case a correspondent writes that he never saw a trace of a paper in connection with the affair and yet there were eight Europeans, besides natives, sleeping under the same roof on that night and none of them could have been included. Such instances of negligence are the subject of conversation on all sides and the organisation appears to have been absurdly defective. This carelessness might lead to very serious consequences from an economic point of view, as the basis of legitimate speculation in real property in the suburbs of Cairo and Alexandria is based on the deductions from the figures of the Census and if Cairo has increased at such a slow pace since the taking of the last Census in 1897 the value of suburban building land cannot be justified.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive attended midday prayers today at the Mosque of Sidi el Abassiri.
To-morrow his Highness will receive in audience Baron Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha and Zagloul Pasha.

div.head: THE BRITISH AGENCY.
div.p: Sir Eldon Gorst is leaving Cairo this after noon at 4 o'clock and will arrive at Sidi Gaber station at 7.15 o'clock with the staff of the British Agency, which from today will be located at Mr. Percy Carver's residence at Bulkeley during the summer season.

div.head: STRANGE AFFAIR AT ZAGAZIG.
div.p: Great excitement prevails at Zagazig owing to the discovery of a remarkable plot to ruin the character of the Mamour of Zagazig Markaz. Some days ago a woman brought an accusation against that official of indecent, assault.

An enquiry was held, which lasted for ten days, and the result of it is that the charge has been shown to be false. It has been also proved that the whole thing is a plot organised by some notables, who are personal enemies of the Mamour. Dr. Nolan, the expert of the Ministry of Justice, proved that the woman was not a virgin. This was also confirmed by local witnesses. The inhabitants are generally dubious as to the truth of the charge. The "cause celebre" has aroused a great deal of local interest.

div.head: ANNIVERSARY BANQUET.
div.p: To-morrow there will be a banquet at the San Stefano Hotel in honour of the seventieth anniversary of the birthday of the vice-president of the Alexandria Municipality, which will occur on Sunday next. Dr. Schiess Pasha came to Egypt in 1869 from Crete. He was invited here by Ismail Pasha to take part in the inaugural ceremony of the Suez Canal. He took up his resilience at Alexandria, where he held the following posts in succession : Sanitary Inspector of the city, Sanitary Delegate for Russia, Physician to the Government Hospital and from 1885 Director of that institution. In 1906 he retired as honorary physician to the hospital and the rank of Pasha was bestowed on him. He has been a member of the Municipal Council since the creation of the Municipality in virtue of his position as sanitary physician to the city. During his career here he has taken a lively interest in all the most important questions relative to the welfare of Egypt's commercial capital. As chairman of the committee of the Alexandria Museum he has done his utmost to promote the efficiency of that institution. Since 1906 he has been vice president of the Municipal Commission. He is also chairman of the Order of the Medical Profession of Alexandria and chairman of the Anti-Tuberculosis League.
The banquet to-morrow will be solely confined to the medical profession. We believe that the physicians of the Sanitary Department at Alexandria will present an address and a souvenir to the Pasha.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor sailed from Tripoli (Barbary) yesterday afternoon and is due here on Sunday.
The Ellerman liner Assiout sailed from Malta this morning for Tripoli and Alexandria.

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
BRITISH CONSULS.
div.p: The latest questions asked about Egypt in the House of Commons are as follows:—
Mr. C. Price. (Edinburgh, Central). — Have any of the Consuls, employed in Egypt, received any commercial training ? Has not Germany several Consuls in Egypt having business qualifications ?
Sir E. Grey. I am not aware of the particular qualifications of the German Consuls, but with regard to the whole Consular Service our effort is to encourage commercial training.
MINISTRY OF JUSTICE.

Mr. John Robertson.—To ask the Secretary ot State for Foreign Affairs, what is the number of British judges and other British judicial officers attached to the Ministry of Justice in Egypt ; and what is their rate of increase since the conclusion of the Anglo-French Agreement of 8th April 1904.

Sir Edward Grey. — I have no information which enables me to answer the hon member's question, but he can find particulars respecting the numbers and rate of increase of the European staff of the Egyptian Ministry of Justice in Lord Cromer's last report. I will make enquiry as to the further information asked for.
THE DAY OF REST.

Mr. John Robertson.—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, why, seeing that Friday is the Moslem day of rest, there is not the same restriction of hours on that day as on Sundays in the postal service at Cairo and Alexandria ; and whether the Customs offices are closed on Sundays and open on Fridays.

Sir E. Grey.—I do not know what the facts are and I am not aware that any complaint has been made on the points referred to in the question. But it is clearly a matter which must be left to the discretion of the Egyptian Government.

div.head: COMMERCIAL HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY.
div.p: At the last meeting of the committee of the Commercial Horticultural Society at Ghezireh the Secretary's report showed that the society will be in a position to spend £600 on the purchase of new and useful plants during the next half year. Arrangements are therefore being made to report consignments of the best varieties of oranges and lemons from Jaffa, Corfu, and Spain, from which large quantities may he propagated for distribution throughout Egypt. During the course of the meeting the cultivation of mangoes in Egypt came up for discussion. As was pointed out, this fruit grows remarkably well here, and not only is there an increasing demand for it in the local markets, but Egypt is the only country from which mangoes can be successfully exported to the European markets. At the present time fully developed trees bring enormous profits to their owners. Unfortunately, like many other fruit-trees, the mango cannot be depended upon to produce fruit of good quality if grown from seed. To perpetuate any desired variety it is necessary to graft the branchlets on young seedling plants. The society has already received a consignment of young plants from India, but as these will not for some time supply cuttings to graft a sufficient number of plants, the committed decided to obtain another and larger consignment.
The next subject to be discussed by the committee was the Sisal Hemp industry. This fibre is the product of a plant known scientifically as Agave rigida.

The principal supplies at present come from the Central American States but the amount produced is by no means equal to the demand. The plant succeeds on the poorest soil and with little water so that it is peculiarly adapted for cultivation on the lands bordering the desert region of Egypt. Experiments carried out at Katta prove that from £1K per feddan clear profit can he realized under such conditions. With the object of propagating large number of these plants the secretary was asked to visit and report as to the suitability of 200 feddans of land at Tel-El-Kebir.

From the report presented to the committee it was gleaned that five feddans at Ghizeh are to he devoted to the propagation of trees of various sorts, but principally those of economic value. The committee is also acting as an Advisory body in the direction of the Orman Garden. The intention here is to plant orna mental trees and shrubs along the sides of the roads and to utilize the centre of the plots experimental purposes in the cultivation of fruit and vegetables. Large areas are now being prepared for the multiplication of banana plants, which is another crop to which the society is giving special attention. There is no doubt that the cultivation of bananas for important industries in Egypt. Large cultivators are now realizing from £80 to £90 net profit per year. At the meeting yesterday it was intimated that an arrangement had been concluded with Messrs. Suttons & Sons, seedsmen, to supply vegetable-seeds at reduced prices for distribution in Egypt.

Before the meeting closed the committee considered the question of horticultural education and the training of men to take charge of private gardens or commercial plantations. A scheme drawn up by Prince Hussein Kamel Pasha was considered the most practicable.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
THIRD SUMMER MEETING.
div.p: Though the attendance at the first day of the third summer meeting of the Alexandria Sporting Club, which was held yesterday afternoon, was very meagre, the afternoon was one of the most, enjoyable which we have spent on the Ibrahimieh course. The weather was all that could be desired, the running was good, interest was sustained in each race up to the finish, and the betting was lively. The hand of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, under the baton of Mr. Fawcett, gave an exceptionally well-chosen selection of music, each item of which was very well rendered. We must also congratulate Mr. Wilkinson on the smart manner in which the Pari Mutuel was conducted. In our account of the last meeting we drew attention to the length of time the backers had to wait before the figures of the Pari Mutuel appeared on the board, but on this occasion the period of waiting was reduced to a minimum and the improvement was noted on all hands. Winners found that payment was made smartly and everyone was satisfied.

The most exciting race of the afternoon was the Ottoman Handicap, which resulted in a dead heat between Valentino and Jourham, with Gouvernant second, and Aida third. The run off between the two firsts was almost as exciting, both horses ran neck and neck all the way round the course. To those who were not opposite the winning post it looked like a second dead heat but the judges gave the verdict to Jourham. Valentino was the favourite and to place backers only paid P.T. 26, whereas Jourham paid for his win at the second effort P.T. 627. The Encouragement Stakes was also an exciting race. Red Cedar was a hot favourite, and Aurelius was also well backed. For the greater part of ihe course Red Cedar looked liked a winner, but in the last stretch was overhauled by Aurelius and only came in a good second.
H.H. Prince Omar Pasha Toiissoun's b.c.c.b.h. Jourham, N.7. Gilbey. 1
Ibrahim Bey Cherifs b.a.h. Valentino, 8.7. Batty. 2

The start was good and Gouvernant leading drew well ahead and led half way round the course with Valentino and Jourham on his heals. Valentino took the lead, but in the last fifty yards Jourham drew up slightly and just as the post was reached drew level, a dead heat resulting. Aida was a poor third, being easily beaten for second place by Koukidis on Gouvernant.
After the sixth race, Jourham and Valentino ran the course again to decide which should he given first place, and after a neck and neck run tor the whole distance Jourham won by a head.

Whiteside, however, pulled Tokar in front and won in splendid style by a short length, Abou Gebel being second, and Nadim a good third.

div.head:
THE MENZALEH CANAL AND NAVIGATION CO.
ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company was held at the offices of the company in Cairo on the 20th inst. Seven thousand one hundred and thirty six shares were represented. The annual report and the balance sheet were approved.

Sir John G. Rogers, the chairman, gave some further figures to the shareholders present as to the receipts of the company for the first 4 months of the current year 1907. The total receipts for passengers and freight from the 15th of February to the 31st of December 1906 amounted to LE 1494. The total receipts for the period 1st January to 30th April amounted fo L.E. 1297, or nearly as much as the total receipts for the whole of the previous years. The daily average of receipts went up from L.E. 6 in January, to L.E. 16 in April. The steady progress reported was considered very satisfactory.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COMPANIES
G. NUNGOVICH EGYPTIAN HTOELS CO.
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration a soumis les comptes suivants sur le huitième exercice social de la Compagnie.

Après acquittement d'une somme de L.E. 9.967,796 pour réparations et'remplacements, de tous les frais d'exploitation et d'Administration, et d'une somme de L E. 2.340. — pour amortissement d'obligations et d'un tiers des frais d'émission d'obligations, il reste un b'nè- fice net pour l'Exercice de :
Sur cette somme il y a lieu de prélever un premier dividende de 5 % aux actions soit sur 37.000 actions de £4 == £7.400 7.215, —
Ce qui laisse un solde de L.E. 33.831,515 Conformément aux prescriptions des statuts, sur ce montant il doit être fait un prélèvement de 10 % pour la réserve „ 3.303,
il est attribué selon l'article 36 des statuts dix pour cent au Conseil d'Adiministration ,, 3.044,
laissant un montant disponible de L.E. 27.404,515
auquel il y a lieu d'âjouter, les 3.217 L.E. reparties l'an dernier, en sorte qu'il reste un total disponible de 30.621 L.E.
Sur la proposition du Conseil il est distribué un dividende supplémentaire de 2.070, soit 28.800 L.R et le solde 1.761 L.E. est reparti à nouveau.
Ces résultats attestent suffisamment la bonne gestion et la prospérité de la Société.
Le Président confirme la vente du Savoy Hotel, de ses dépendances et dn terrain situé en face pour la somme globale de 463.597 L.E. laissant un bénéfice de 330.181 L.E.

Les bruits qui ont couru de l'abandon de cet achat sont entièrement dénués de fonde ment et la société des "Egyptian Estates," qui adéjv versé on accompte de 20.000 L.E., remplira complètement ses engagements jusqu'au bout.

Sor la proposition de M. Midani il est convenu qu'une Assemblée Générale extraordinaire sera convoquée procliainèment pour modifier le paragraphe 2 de l'article 36 des statuts concernant l'obligation de mettre chaque année à la réserve 10 % des bénéfices nets.

Les réserves, atteignent actuellement 96.112 L. E., sont suffisantes pour assurer les revenus de la Société pendant de nombreuses années. M. Midani désire qu'il ne soit plus rien versé à la réserve et que tout le bénéfice soit désormais distribué aux actionnaires.

Avant de lever la séance, M. Rostowitz bey annonce l'achat définitif du Casino de San Stefano pour la somme de 140.000 L.E. 11 y a 55. pics, 180 chambres, dont 100 nouvellement aménagées et meublées ; des bâtiments actuels ont coûté 68.000 L.E. et les revenus annuels atteignent 12.000 L.E., chiffre qui n a jamais été dépassé par lé Savoy Hûtel. Il eu résulte que les revenus de la Société ne seront en rien diminués et que le capital productif sera diminué de la difference entre 463.000 et 140. L.E., soit 323.000 L.E., qui deviendront disponibles pour être réparties entre les actionnaires.
En outre, la vente du Continental Hûtel sera un fait accompli avant la fin de l'année et, aussitôt sa réalisation, il sera distribué un boni de 20 L.E. par action.
Les actionnaires ne peuvent que féliciter le Conseil d'administration de la façon brillante avec laqelle il a conduit leurs affaires.

div.head: COMPAGINE AGRICOLE DU NIL.
div.p: Les résultats des travaux de cette Société pour la première année sont résumés comme suit dans le dernier rapport du Conseil d'Administration :

Affaires Rurales : Concentrant principalement nos efforts sur les opérations du domaine rural, nous y avons consacré la presque totalité de nos ressources. Le choix heureux de Cha- rabas dont nous pouvons à juste titre nous flatter, montre le soin et la circouspection que nous avons apportés dans nos opérations. Ce domaine, inscrit au bilan pour son prix de revient, et sans tenir compte de la plus-value qu'il a déjà acquise, représente une réserve latente pour l'avenir.

Du côté de l'exploitation les résultats sont d'autant plus satisfaisants qu'ils ont été obtenus sans revente. Malgré les mauvaises conditions de la réoolte cotonière et quoique notre exploitation succédât à une période de fermage généralement négligé en Egypte, le revenu de la première année s'est élevé à 4,50% environ. Nous espérons que ce résultat pourra être amélioré graduellement, grâce aux procédés de culture que nous appliquons et à la bonne organisation de notre exploitation.

Affaires Urbaines : Les affaires -urbaines n'ont pas été sans attirer notre attention. Nous ne pouvions, en effet, rester indifférents au mouvement général qui s'est porté sur cette branche d'affaires, mouvement déterminé par l'action combinée de facteurs divers, au nombre desquels il convient de citer la sollicitude plus marquée du Gouvernement égyptien pour l'embellissement des villes.

Totttefois, prenant pour règle de ne nous engager qu'avec une juste prudence et après nous être entourés do tous les éléments de sécurité, nous avons consacré une partie de notre activité à oes affaires. Il est à remarquer surtout que le suocès de nos opérations n'est pas dû à un effet aocidentel de la spéculation ; nos acheteurs ont pu, en effet, vendre et continuent encore à revendre avec bénéfice.

D'ailleurs, dans toutes ces affaires, nous nous sommes associés avec des groupes amis qui nous ont prêté le concours de leurs capitaux. Pour les opérations de Zawiah-EI- Hamrah et de Chouhrah, nos co-participants nous ont confié la gestion des entreprises d'achat et de vente, que nous croyons avoir conduites jusqu'à 'présent à notre satisfaction commune. J'es résultats de notre Compte de Profits et Pertes le montrent d'ailleurs suffisamment.
Le Domaine de Clmrabns est d'une contenance de 1492 feddans situé dans la Moudi- rieh de Dakhalieh entre Mansourah et Damiette. Le prix de revient est de fr. 2,589,135.
Les bénéfices nets sont de fr. 348,237.24 Après divers amortissements un dividende de 5% a été déclaré sur les actions de capital et une somme de fr. 118,455 a été reportée a nouveau.

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPHE URBANORA.
div.p: Jeudi prochain 30 Mai aura lieu l'inauguration du'nouveau local sis à la rue Salnh El Din, près la rue Chérif Pacha. On prépare à cette occasion un programme qui sera une véritable merveille. La Direction n'a épargné aucun sacrifice afin de pourvoir le nouveau local d'une installation aussi luxueuse que riche.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Jeudi 23 Mai 1907.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est remonté hier de 1/8 à 3/4 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1 /8 à 84 7/8, L'Unifiée a haussé de 1,4 à 100 1/4. La National Bank a regagné 5/8 à 22 3/8 et l'Agricole 1/8 à 8 3 8. La Daira Sanieh et la Dëlta Light sont restées in variées à 15 et à 9 3/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a regagné 7 francs à 718. La Banque d'Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 128.

Encouragé d'un coté par la meilleure tenue des valeurs égyptiennes à Londres et à Paris, d'autre côté par la persistance des rumours relatives au succès des démarches faites ces jours derniers pour améliorer la situation locale, notre marché a montré, ce matin, une animation de bon aloi et d'excollentes dispositions pour une regrise. Espérons que ce mouvement se maintiendra ; toujours est il qu'il y a ou des achats suivis-en National Bank, en Agricole et en plusieurs autres titres.
La National Bank, fort mouvementée, a passé de 21 15/16 à 22 11/16-3/4.
L'Agricole a gagné 3/16 à 8 3/8. La Banque d'Athènes q bénéficié d'environ 5 francs à 128- 129.
Le Crédit Foncier s'est inscrit à 712 ; l'obligation à lots ancienne a faibli à 317. L'Union Foncièro est revenue à 5 1/8.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire sont montées à 223. Les Héliopolis ont été négociées à 270.
Les H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd. ont été l'objet de nombreux échanges entre £ 1 et 1 1/16 ; leur part a été traitée à £ 5.
Les New Egyptian ont été mieux tenus qu'hier à 17 sh. 7 1/2 et les Walker and Meimarachi à $ 0 1/2.

Le nombre des opérations enregistrées en corbeille a été de 62 ; mais, do mémo qu'hier, il y a èu un chiffre considérable d'opérations non insolites, pratiquées à des prix divers sur les titrés dopt les coins sont fixés pnr la cote de compensation établie le. 22 Avril dernier.
Le prochain numéro de notre Circulaire ne parajîtra que lundi prochain 27 Mai cou rant, la Bourse étAnt fermée demain ainsi que samedi.
Nous détachons do notre correspondant de Londres, en date du 17 Mai, le passage suivant :

" Les valeurs égyptiennes ont eu, cette remaillé encore, un marché très restreint au Stock Exchange, avec tendance à la faiblesse. Des ventes d'un caractère plus ou moins forcé ont été de nouveadi effectuées pour compte de l'Egypte. La National Bank a fléchi à 23 1/4 et l'Agricole à 8 9,16. La New Egyptian est tombée à £ U 15/16 ex- coupon, les Estates à 1 3/8 et les United Lands à £ 0 9/16. Des transactions ont eu Heu en Epargne Immobilière Ltd. à 2 5/8. Quelques affaires ont été également pratiquées en Comptoir Financier, dont: le cours de clôture de ce soir est de 4 1 /2.
" L'argent pour les reports a été très abon dant et 1es taux en général ont été d'environ 12 pour cent moins chers qu'à la liquidation précédente. "
L'Assemblée générale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. Rera tenue, au siège social au Caire,dans la deuxième quinzaine du mois de Juin prochain.

Si nos informations sont exactes,le conseil d'administration proposera le paiement d'un dividende de 2 sh. 6 par action, soit 12 1/2 pour cent sur fo capital nommai. En outre, un dividende intérimaire d'environ 3 sh. sur l'exercice en cours pourra être déclaré en septembre prochain.
L'assembléo générale ordinaire de la George Nungovich Hotels Co. s'est tenue hier au Grand Continental Hotel.
Il résulte du rapport du conseil d'administration que les bénéfices nets de l'exercice écoulé ont été de L.E. 41,046.

Après prélèvement de l'intérêt statutaire de 5 % et, sur le solde, de 10 % pour la réserve et 10 % au conseil d'administiation, il est resté un montant disponible de L.E. 27,404,formant avec je reliquat de l'année précédente un total de L.E. 30,621.

L'assemblée a approuvé les comptes et, sur la proposition du conseil, a décidé la répartition d'un dividende supplémentaire de 20 % aux actions, soit L.E. 28,860. Une somme de L,E. 1,761 a été reportée à nouveau. Le divi- dende total par action eat donc de P.E. 100.
M. George Royle, administrateur sortant, a été réélu.

div.head:
THE IRISH QUESTION.
LIBERALS MUCH PERTURBED

div.p: The Irish deadlock continues to engross the papers. The Unionists continue to ridicule the Government and advise Mr. Birrell to resign. The Radicals deny that a crisis exists, while admitting the seriousness of the blow. They advise the Government to concentrate its efforts towards English reform and to make the Land Bill the real fighting Bill. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE IENA EXPLOSION.
NEW VENTILATION SYSTEM.

div.p: As the result of the enquiry regarding the Iena explosion an Admiralty order directs the immediate installation of a new system of ventilation in the magazines of British warships by means of carbonic acid gas. (Reuter)

The Government has decided to offer financial relief measures to the distressed winegrowers in the South. It will introduce a bill heavily taxing sugar used for adulteration purposes and permitting the closing of premises of wine merchants discovered selling adulterated wines. (Reuter)
A brilliant reception was given to the delegates of the London University at the Elysée place. Mr. Fallieres enlogised the relations existing between the two nations. (Havas)

div.head:
THE WHEAT FAMINE.
PRICE OF BREAD.

div.p: Owing to fresh reports of the damage of crops in Russia, Rumania, and America, the rise in the price of bread is becoming general. It appears certain that it will reach 5 1/2 d, per l loaf. (Reuter)

div.head:
JAPANESE SQUADRON CRUISE.
TO VISIT GERMANY.

div.p: The "Vos Gazette" learns that the Japanese squadron, coming from America, will first call at an English port, then a French port, and after that will visit Kiel during the regatta. The invitation was issued by the Emperor after the Japanese Government had intimated that it would regard with pleasure the prospect of its squadron visiting a German port. (R.)
43 Rand mines are effected by the strike. (Reuter)
The strike on the Rand is affecting South African Bank shares. Any stoppage of the regular supply of gold would seriously affect the monetary position in Europe. (Reuter)
In view of the situation caused by the strike Imperial troops have been despatched here from Pretoria.

According to a telegram received from Teheran attempts to deprive Armenians and Parsees of franchise has led to protests from all cities uncompanied by threats to emigrate to India. The disturbances are becoming worse. Anti dynastic proclamations are appearing in Teheran. The Shah's brother, the Governor Luristan, is stirring up the warlike, nomad: and collecting troops. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
Liverpool, May 16th.
Egyptian Cotton on the spot is quite neglected, there being scarcely sufficient business doing to test quotations, which me nominally 1/16 plb. lower.
In Futures only moderate business has taken place, and the following are the latest values :—
June 10.— Sep. 9.60 Dec. 9.44 Mar. 9.40
July 10— Oct. 9.57 Jan. 9.41

American Futures -The market this week has been active, and prices have experienced a material advance. To-day there has been a sharp reaction, but closing values are 9 @ 13 points higher than those of last Thursday. The advance has been chiefly due to the continuance of very unfavorable weather throughout the Cotton Area ; heavy rains, and temperatures below normal are causing serious apprehension. With this there has been the manipulation of the near positions, and large covering of the new Crop of which there had undoubtedly been considerable shortage. The outlook is without doubt an anxious one, and making all allowances for exaggeration it requires an immediate change to much more favorable conditions to diminish the present nervous feeling.
The latest quotations are, delivery:—

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN SUDAN.
ITS HISTORY AND MONUMENTS.
div.p: Dr. Wallis Budge's new book on the Sudan is an encyclopaedic compilation. It embraces an account of the four archaeological missions to that country and a review of the researches of other travellers and archæologists in Nubia and the Egyptian Sudan. There is also a history of the Sudan from its earliest beginnings to the fall of Mahdism. There are chapters on the gold mines, and Christianity and the last portion of the work gives good descriptive account of the progress made under British rule. The author has had considerable experience in the Sudan. In the summer of 1897, by arrangement with the Sirdar Sir H. Kitchener, the trustees of the British Museum sent him on an archeological mission there. By the end of the year he had examined the Pyramid-fields at Nuri, Kurrû, Zuma, and Tankasi, had opened one of the pyramids at Gebel Barkal and had dug through portions of the ruined temples on this site. In the winter of 1898-99 he was again sent to the Sudan and was permitted to examine the four groups of Pyramids which stand near the site of the ancient city of Meroe with a view excavating the most important of them hen an opportunity offered. In the winter of 1900-01 it was proposed to carry on excavations on the Island of Meroe, but as owing to the lack ot population, no labour was forthcoming, the project had to be abandoned. In the spring of 1902 Sir Reginald Wingate, who hail succeeded Lord Kitchener as Sirdar, made arrangements for excavating the group of the largest pyramids at Meroe, and Dr. Budge was sent to the Sudan to conduct the archaeological portion of the work. As a result of the excavation made at this time it was found that the chambers in which the dead were placed were beneath the Pyramids as in Egypt, and not in the Pyramids as some had supposed ; that the bodies of native kings and queens were not mummified and that the chambers of the dead were not filled with funerary furniture, as is usually the case in Egypt. Beneath several of the smaller Pyramids large jars half filled with sand and ashes of human bones were found in small vaulted chambers, a fact which proved that the bodies of several members of the ruling class at Meroe were burnt. Thus the expectation that, the pyramids of Meroe would yield a rich harvest of sepulchral antiquities was not fulfilled.

In the spring of 1905 the author was sent to the Sudan to assist Sir R. Wingate in collecting antiquities tor the newly established museum at Khartoum, and with Mr. J. W. Crowfoot, inspector of Education, he examined all the principal sites from Sesi, or Sesesbi to Semna ; the antiquities at several of these had suffered considerably since he first visited them. They collected a number of objects of importance and were fortunate enough to discover at Semna a hitherto unknown temple of Tirhaka, which was dedicated to Usertsen III., the great Egyptian conqueror of the Sudan about B.C. 2333. Their work at the island of Gazirat-al-Malik also yielded good results, and they removed from the top of the hill on which the old Egyptian fortress stood a fine stele of Usertsen III. At Meroe they succeeded in clearing out the shrine of one of the pyramids, ami in taking down the North and South walls; the former is now at Khartoum, and the latter in the British museum.

During the years in which Dr. Budge was thus occupied in the Sudan he collected materials for a history of the country, and the present work is the result. The first part contains a brief narrative of the results of the missions, and a description of the temples, pyramids, etc. ; which by the friendly help and co-ojieration of Lord Kitchener, Sir R. Wingate, and their staffs Dr. Budge was able to visit, examine and partly exevate. He has prefaced this narrative by a summary of the splendid archaeological work done in the Sudan by modern travellers, especially by Cailliaud, Hoskins, and Lepsius, and to this a notice of the troubles of Poncet, Norden Gau, Brown, Burkhardt, Legh, Hamburg, Waddington, Russeger and others has been added.

The second part of the book deals with the history of the Sudan. The narrative begins with the great raid made in the country by Seneferu, a king of Egypt, who reigned about B.C. 3766, and ends with a summary of the principal events which took place there A.D. 1904. We must not assume that the raid of Seneferu was the first which the Egyptians made in the Sudan, for the Egyptian monuments of the pro-dynastic and archaic periods yield sufficient evidence to justify us in believing that it was only one of a very long series which began some thousands of years before that king came to the throne. Details of such raids are at present wanting, but it is quite certain that every ruler ot Egypt, in all periods, has considered the Sudan simply as the country which produces slaves and gold.

In spite of this, however, the history Egypt shows that the peoples of the Sudan influenced in no small degree the ancient Egyptian religion and civilization and doubt it is this fact which caused historians like Diodorus to assert that the civilization of Egypt had its origin in Ethiopia, by which of course he meant the country of the black sun burnt peoples i.e., the Southern Sudan. The Eastern and Northern conquerors of Egypt in the Dynastic period imposed the veneer of their civilization upon the Egyptians with considerable success, but in fundamentals of belief and custom, the Egyptians even in the Ptolemaic period had more in common with the black skinned, but non negro tribes of the Southern Sudan than is usually admitted.

For the history of the Sudan from about B.C. 4000 to the period of the rise of the Nubian kingdom under Piankhi about B.C. 750, the authorities are the Egyptian monuments and much light is thrown upon the state of the country and the conquests made by its kings from about 700 to 600 B.C. by the stelae of Tannath-amen, Aspelta, and Nastasen. On the history of the next 1150 years native monumfents are silent but it is clear that during this interval the great kingdom of the Sudan was split into two parts, the northern living its capital at Napata, or Merawi some forty miles south of the mouth of the Atbara. The Greek and Rorman writers, especially Herodotus, Diodorus, Strabo and Pliny, supply descriptions of the peoples of the Sudan, excellent on the whole, even in the places somewhat fanciful but of the history of the country they tell us nothing.

In the early centuries of our era Christianity penetrated the Sudan via Egypt and it had permeated the minds of the Nubians so thoroughly that, in the second quarter of the sixth century, a native king called Silko succeeded in establishing a Christian kingdom in the Northern Sudan and made Dongola his capital.
This kingdom flourished for some seven hundred years and proved an effective barrier to the advance of Islam.

Facts for the history of the Sudan from the time of its conquest by the Arabs about A.D. 650 to the end of the 15th century, are scanty, but Mohamedan writers supply us with a number of statements which enable us to piece together a fairly connected narrative.

It is clear that the Northern Sudan was subject to the Khalifas and their representatives in Egypt, and that its rulers were compelled by them to pay the "Bakht" or annual tributes of slaves. It is equally clear however that, the native Christian Chinch made a persistent and gallant stand against Islam, and that Christianity flourished in the country from the 1st Cataract, to Sôba on the Blue Nile. The testimony of Mohamedan writers proves that there were hundreds of Churches in the country between these limits, and we know from other sources that many of them were fine buildings, the walls of which were decorated with painted figures of saints etc.

The form of belief which the Sudan Christians professed was that of Alexandria, i.e. Jacobites and the liturgy was recited in Greek, and we may assume that the chief members of the clergy came from the Mother Church in Alexandria.

In the 13th century, however, troubles came on the native church, and in proportion as the power and influence of Islam grew and spread, Christianity declined. Little by little mosques appeared in the towns and villages, and as the patriarchs of Alexandria were unable to assist the Sudan church in stemming the flood of Mohamedanism which was sweeping over the land, the clergy lost their hold upon the people many of whom both voluntarily and under compulsion, rejected Christianity and became followers of the prophet.

The southern portion of the Christian kingdom of the Sudan, that of Alwa, came to an end toward the close of the 15th century, and by the time Selim conquered Egypt in 1517, the alters of Christ had been profaned or overthrown, and the churches were forsaken buildings.

When the Arabs entered the Western Sudan from Tunis and the Eastern Sudan from Massawa, and the Northern Sudan via Egypt, Islam finally prevailed over Christianity, and from the year 1520 to the present, time, the population of the whole Sudan has consisted practically of Mohamedans and Pagans.

With the facts at present available it is impossible to write a connected history of the country between 1520 and 1820, but we know that during this period Sultans ruled in Dar-Fur "Meks" or "Chiefs" in Shendi, Albanians in Nubia, and lines of hereditary tribal Sheikhs in other parts of the Sudan.

These waged war with each other in true Sudani fashion whensoever opportunity offered, the object, of each being to capture as many slaves and women and as much gold as possible, and destroy the enemy and his country.

The methods employed were always the same, and seem to be inherent in the race. The accounts of the "wars" carried on by the petty kings of the Sudan during the last three or four centuries strikingly resemble certain portions of the annals of the Nubian king Nastasen, who defeated Cambyses, and conquered the Sudan about B.C. 525. A good summary of Sudan history from 1504 to 1871 is contained in an Arabic manuscript presented by Gordon to the British Museum, which Dr. Budge considers to be worth editing and translating. From 1820 the history of the Sudan is comparatively well known.

From these materials Dr. Budge has compiled his present work, which will be the standard book of reference on the subject for many years to come. We will deal will various portions of the book in subsequent issues.
* The Egyptian Sudan, its history and monuments, by E. A. Wallis Budge, with numerous illustrations. In two volumes. Published by Kegan Paul, Trench, Trubner & Co., Ltd. London, 1907.

div.head: FROM THE NIGER TO THE NILE.
div.p: At a meeting of the Royal Geographical Society held at the Theatre, Burlington gardens, Lieutenant Boyd Alexander delivered a lecture on " An Expedition from the Niger, by Lake Chad, to the Nile. " Sir George Goldie, the president, was in the chair, and there was a large attendance.

Lieutenant Alexander, in the course of his lecture, said that the first work which the expedition, of which he was leader, wished to carry out was a systematic survey of a portion of Northern Nigeria. Secondly, they wanted to explore Lake Chad, and the rivers between the Niger and the Nile, with the idea of demonstrating the wonderful system of waterways that connected the west with the east, and he thought that this was fairly well shown when he told them that in the three years which the journey took to complete, the boats were carried for only 14 days. Together with these primary objects special attention was to be given to tribal distribution and orthography of native names, and a careful study made of the distribution of the fauna to prove its affinity between the West Coast and the Nile. The party consisted of Captain G. B. Gosling, Mr. P. A. Talbot, his brother, Captain Claud Alexander, and himself. With him he took his Portuguese collector, Jose Lopes. The expedition left England on February, 27, 1904, and arrived at Lokoja on March 24. They left a few days later for Ibi, on the Benue, where the survey work was begun in earnest, the object being to triangulate through the country north to Bauchi and connect that place with their subsequent work in Bomu. The lecturer described the journey of the survey party to Asharka, which was readied on August 17, and which was the rendezvous of the expedition after leaving Ibi. He then drew attention to his own journey through the centre of Nigeria, where he made zoological collections, and gave some interesting details of the country through which he passed and its peoples. On October 26 he arrived at. Yo, which was about three hours from Lake Chad, and was to be their next base. Speaking again of the survey party, he said that at Daliwa, where the journey was particularly arduous, his brother, who only recently had had an attack of fever, collapsed, and died at Maifoni on November 13. Five days later Mr. Talbot and the lecturer left Maifoni with the object of carrying on a vigorous traverse to Kukawa, at which place the labours which wore embodied in the map now published in the "Geographical Journal'' came to an end. From Kukawa they went to Kaddlo, the new base from which they were to carry out their survey of the lake. After alluding to the valuable work which French officers had done in the exploration and mapping of Lake Chad in recent years, Lieutenant Alexander remarked that he thought it best to confine himself to his own explorations, and leave it to geographers to deal as a whole with the information thus placed at their disposal. Lake Chad, he maintained, was considerably smaller than it was formerly supposed to be. For instance, the northern part, which used to be marked on the maps as 60 miles across, he found to he not more than 30 miles, and his journey across the centre made it only 56 miles instead of 90. There was an idea that the lake was drying up, but his opinion was that it did not alter very much. His observations went to show that the lake was practically two lakes, divided by the 15 miles or so of marsh and maria hush that he attempted to cut through, and these formed the separate basins of the two rivers. Moreover, a Buduma chief told him that there was no communication between the two parts, and he found that the people on the different sides knew little of each other. On May 26, 1905, after three months' exploration of the lake, he reached the delta of the Shari, which was composed of three main channels and three smaller ones. He gave some particulars of the course of the Shari, which flowed through a very flat country, and described the inhabitants with whom he came in contact. They arrived at the French post of Krebedge, on the Tomi river, on October 13, and a journey of four days down this river brought them into the Nbanghi. Yakomn, a large Belgian post, at the mouth of the Welle river, was reached on January 1, 1906, and while on their journey up the river they succeeded in capturing an okapi, in the neighbourhood of Angu. It was at Niangaro, the lecturer proceeded, that the expedition received its last great blow in the death of Captain Gosling. Lieutenant Alexander afterwards ascended the Kibali river, which had never before been navigated, and on July 21 arrived at N'soro, a small Belgian post. They attempted the ascent of the river Ira or Bakwa, which up till now had been considered the main stream of the Kibali. But this was not the case, for the N'soro, which fell into tho Kibali some three miles below tho post of that name, was really the main stream. It was impossible, he found, to ascend the Dungu. He arrived at Yoi on Octolier 13, and, having formed a column to carry his collections to Gondokoro, began the descent of the Yei to the Nilo. A barrier of marsh and sudd choked their passage to the Nile. He had calculated that his passage of the Yei, by showing it to be navigable in its lower reaches, proved that it could be utilized to lessen the transport by six days of the food supplies to our garrisons in the Barh-el Gazell province from Khartum. It was also his opinion that if the barrier of sudd were cut through, the increase of water to the Nile would immensely improve the irrigation of the Sudan and Egypt ; it was also the case with the rivers Nabm and Rol, which flowed more or less parallel with the Yei. With their arrival on the Nile their journey, which in distance had extended over 5,000 miles and in time had occupied just three years, was brought to an end. In conclusion the lecturer said that it was now his greatest hope that the scientific record of the expedition might in some measure repay the price that was paid, for its achievement in valuable lives.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA WATER COMPANY LTD.
div.p: Avis est donné par la présente qu'une Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire de la Compagnie aura lieu au Bureau de la Compagnie à Alexandrie le 11 Juin 1907 à 4 heures et demie de l'après-midi, pour approuver les résolutions suivantes :
1. L'augmentation du capital de la Compagnie par la création de 20,000 nouvelles actions de £5 nominalo chacune, exclusivement offertes aux actionnaires.
2. De donner pouvoirs au Conseil d'Administration d'emettre ces actions, en totalité ou en partie, au moment et au prix qu'il jugera opportun dans l'interét de la Compagnie.
Cette Assemblée aura lieu a la suite de l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire.

Pour assister ou se faire représenter à cette Assemblée, MM. les propriétaires d'actions au porteur sont informés que, conformément aux Statuts, leurs titres doivent être déposés a l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd., à Alexandrie, au moins trois jours francs, avant l'Assemblée, ou chez Messr. Barclay & Company Ltd. 1, Pali Mail East, London, S.W., a Londres, 14 jours francs, avant l'Assemblée.
Par ordre du Conseil d'Administration,
H. R. C. BLAGDEN.
30288-4-2 Directeur.
